results.title: In Russia, as Prices Soar, the Outlook for Its Economy Grows ‘Especially Gloomy’
results.abstract: The government has brought stability for now through extreme measures, but forecasters are expecting continued severe inflation and a deep downturn.
results.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Valeriya Safronova

multimedia.caption: Manezhnaya Square in central Moscow on Monday. The Central Bank of Russia has predicted inflation will run between 18 and 23 percent this year.
multimedia.copyright: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Hooked on Cheap Oil, Hungary Resists an Embargo on Russia
results.abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has promised voters to keep energy prices low. The dividends from taking Russian fuel also help fund the policies that have made Hungary a beacon for right-wing groups.
results.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

multimedia.caption: The Danube Refinery, owned by the Hungarian energy conglomerate MOL, south of Budapest. MOL said last month that it would pay out $652 million in dividends to shareholders.
multimedia.copyright: Akos Stiller for The New York Times

results.title: A Pentagon official says Russian troops have been forced to fight in smaller formations in eastern Ukraine.
Oklahoma Legislature Passes Bill Banning Almost All Abortions
results.abstract: The legislation would be the nation’s strictest, and relies on lawsuits from private citizens to enforce it. If the governor signs the bill, it would take effect immediately.
results.byline: By Kate Zernike, Mitch Smith and Luke Vander Ploeg

multimedia.caption: Oklahoma has been at the head of the pack of Republican-led states rushing to pass laws that restrict or prohibit abortion in anticipation that the Supreme Court is soon likely to overturn Roe v. Wade.
multimedia.copyright: Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters

results.title: ‘I Had to Go Back’: Over 55, and Not Retired After All
results.abstract: After leaving the labor force in unusual numbers early in the pandemic, Americans approaching retirement age are back on the job at previous levels.

multimedia.caption: Kim Williams, 62, lost her job early in the pandemic but has recently gone back to work. “I’m too young to retire, so I had to go back,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: Desiree Rios for The New York Times

results.title: Racists Once Terrorized This Georgia County. Diversity Made It Prosper.
results.abstract: The slow return of diversity to an area that brutally drove out its Black residents has been accompanied by a boom that gives the lie to “Great Replacement” conspiracy theories.

multimedia.caption: Cumming, Ga., is in Forsyth County, where the population is now over 260,000 — up from 45,000 when the vestiges of all-white Forsyth began falling away.
multimedia.copyright: Audra Melton for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Cumming, Ga., is in Forsyth County, where the population is now over 260,000 — up from 45,000 when the vestiges of all-white Forsyth began falling away.
multimedia.copyright: Audra Melton for The New York Times

results.title: Fentanyl Tainted Pills Bought on Social Media Cause Youth Drug Deaths to Soar
results.abstract: Teenagers and young adults are turning to Snapchat, TikTok and other social media apps to find Percocet, Xanax and other pills. The vast majority are laced with deadly doses of fentanyl, police say.

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Dillender, left, and her daughter, Kristin, at home in Texas. In December, Ms. Dillender’s son, Kade Webb, bought counterfeit Percocet through a dealer on Snapchat and died of fentanyl poisoning.
multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Dillender, left, and her daughter, Kristin, at home in Texas. In December, Ms. Dillender’s son, Kade Webb, bought counterfeit Percocet through a dealer on Snapchat and died of fentanyl poisoning.
multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Dillender, left, and her daughter, Kristin, at home in Texas. In December, Ms. Dillender’s son, Kade Webb, bought counterfeit Percocet through a dealer on Snapchat and died of fentanyl poisoning.
multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

results.title: Thousands of Migrants Have Been Waiting for Months to Enter U.S.
results.abstract: People from around the world have been lingering on the border, awaiting the end of pandemic restrictions. Their fate remains one of the Biden administration’s biggest challenges on immigration.

results.abstract: The closely watched case against the man accused of carrying out a racist attack at a Tops supermarket over the weekend will proceed to a grand jury.

results.title: The Enduring Afterlife of a Mass Shooting’s Livestream Online
results.abstract: Dozens of recordings of a 2019 massacre in Christchurch, New Zealand, remain online, in a sobering reminder of the internet’s permanence.
results.byline: By Ryan Mac, Kellen Browning and Sheera Frenkel

multimedia.caption: A memorial outside a Tops Friendly Market in Buffalo, N.Y., last weekend after a mass shooting. The gunman took inspiration from a 2019 rampage in Christchurch, New Zealand, videos of which continue circulating.

results.title: Snowmobiles in Slush: Sports Are on Thin Ice in the Warming Arctic
results.abstract: Skiing, hiking and dogsledding will never be the same in Svalbard, Norway, which has warmed more than twice as quickly as the rest of the Arctic. The islands may be isolated, but the changes aren’t.
results.byline: By Jeré Longman and Erin Schaff

results.title: Puberty Starts Earlier Than It Used To. No One Knows Why.
results.abstract: Some girls are starting to develop breasts as early as age 6 or 7. Researchers are studying the role of obesity, chemicals and stress.

multimedia.copyright: Eleni Kalorkoti
Eleni Kalorkoti

results.title: A Second Bedroom on the Upper West Side for Under $800,000? These Were Their Options.
results.abstract: When they realized they might be able to afford a co-op in their beloved Manhattan neighborhood, two newlyweds contemplated what they were willing to sacrifice to become homeowners.

multimedia.caption: Elise and Michael Cocozzo with Walter on the Upper West Side. The couple, who had been happily renting a one-bedroom in the neighborhood, set a budget of up to $800,000 for a new place with more space and a few upgrades. “If we were going to actually invest in something longer term, we really wanted that second bedroom,” Ms. Cocozzo said.
multimedia.copyright: Katherine Marks for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Elise and Michael Cocozzo with Walter on the Upper West Side. results.title: How a Group of Female Independents Aims to Revive Australian Democracy
results.abstract: A community-driven movement has recruited around 25 candidates, most of them successful women preaching pragmatic reform. They could shape the balance of power after Saturday’s election.

results.title: Do We Really Need to Take 10,000 Steps a Day for Our Health?
results.abstract: The advice that we take 10,000 steps a day is more a marketing accident than based on science. Taking far fewer may have notable benefits.

multimedia.caption: The good news is that upping our current step counts by even a few thousand additional strides most days could be a reasonable, sufficient — and achievable — goal.
multimedia.copyright: TraceyAPhotos/iStock
